title: Introduction to Programming
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: This course introduces computer programming to students with no previous programming experience. Students learn the fundamentals of python programming and learn how to design, implement, test, debug, and document programs. They also learn how to solve problems using object-oriented programming methodology. Most of the examples and assignments will be related to biological questions in genomics and bioinformatics.Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to a.      Master key programming concepts such data-types, variables, conditions, loops and functionsb.     Understand fundamental concepts in object-oriented programing and pattern matchingc.      Solve small to medium size programming tasks that arise in bioinformaticsd.      Write well-structured and maintainable programs in Python
syllabus: Introduction to Computation and Programming;Branching and Iteration;Decomposition and Functions;Lists, Tuples and Strings;Recursion; Dictionaries;Object-Oriented Programming;Python Classes and Inheritance (I);Python Classes and Inheritance (II);Python Classes and Inheritance (III);Biopython;Understanding Program Efficiency;Basic Searching Algorithms;Regular Expressions;Testing, Debugging and Exceptions;More Programming Languages
required_readings: All required readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
recommended_readings: All recommended readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.

title: Introduction to Molecular Biology and Genetics
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: This course introduces students to the molecular mechanisms responsible for the transmission, expression and regulation of genetic information in prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms. Students will also learn the basic concepts of genetics including population genetics, developmental genetics and evolutionary genetics.Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to a. understand basic concepts in biomolecules and cell biology b. know how molecular biology can explain the transmission of genetic information c. correlate molecular biology concepts with genetic and phenotypic traits
syllabus: Introduction to Biomolecules; Basic Cell Biology; DNA and Chromatin Structure; DNA Replication, Repair and Recombination; Control of Gene Expression; Methods in Molecular Biology; Genomic Applications in Biomedical Research; Molecular Genetics of Menedelian Diseases; Molecular Genetics of Complex Diseases; Population Genetics; Evolutionary Genetics
required_readings: All required readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
recommended_readings: 1. Molecular Biology of the Cell, Fourth Edition by Bruce Alberts, Alexander Johnson 2. Human Molecular Genetics, Fourth Edition by Tom Strachan, Andrew Read

title: Bio-computing
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: This course covers several computational technologies in bioinformatics. First, students learn the fundamentals of Linux OS and shell and learn how to accustom themselves to the Linux computing environment for routine bioinformatics tasks. Students also learn how to run and install common bioinformatics tools from the command line. In the second half of this course, students learn the basic statistical methods for bioinformatics, and how to use R to conduct statistical tests and create graphs for bioinformatics questions. Hands-on practice is provided throughout the whole course, whereas a comprehensive genomics project enhances students’ learning on the technologies above mentioned.Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able toa. accustom themselves to Linux computing environmentb. acquire the usage of common bioinformatics toolsc. employ common statistical methods for bioinformatics problems using R
syllabus: Introduction to Linux computational environment; Working with Linux (I); Working with Linux (II); Common bioinformatics tools (I);  Common bioinformatics tools (II); Common bioinformatics tools (III); Common bioinformatics tools (IV);  Introduction to programming with R (I); Introduction to programming with R (II); Basic statistical methods for bioinformatics (I); Basic statistical methods for bioinformatics (II); High performance computing;
required_readings: All required readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
recommended_readings: UNIX and Linux System Administration Handbook (5th Edition). Addison-Wesley Professional. 2017

title: Genomics: Basic Concepts and Applications
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: This course introduces the basic concepts of genomics. It covers the structure and organization of human genome, and the strategies that are used to map, sequence and analyse the genomes. Students learn how to make connections between genomic data and the relevant biological questions. They also learn how genomic sequence information is utilized biomedicine including pharmacogenomics, drug discovery, diagnostics and personalized medicine.Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to a. acquire the basic concept of genomics b. learn the principle, strategies and limitations of genomic technology  c. apply genomics to solve biological and biomedical questions
syllabus: Introduction to genomics; An overview of large scale genomic projects; Genomic sequencing and data analysis; Genome assembly: a key step towards comprehensive genomic maps; Functional annotation of genomes: gene, mutation, and SNP; Workshop I & II; Functional annotation of genomes (transcriptional regulation, transcriptome analysis, noncoding RNA and single cell sequencing), Medical genomics
required_readings: All required readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
recommended_readings: All recommended readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.

title: Theories and Algorithms in Bioinformatics
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: This course introduces the basic concepts underlying the theoretical basis of common bioinformatics algorithms. It covers the topics of sequence alignment, phylogeny, motifs finding, assembly, and metagenomics. Students learn these topics by attending lectures, classroom activities, and getting hands-on experience through assignments.Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to Describe biological problems from an algorithmic perspective. Appreciate the computational ideas underlying common bioinformatics algorithms. Understand the strengths and weaknesses of existing algorithms, and interpret their results appropriately. Conduct scientific and technical communications with biologists, bioinformaticians and computer scientists.
syllabus: Sequence Alignment and searching; Molecular phylogenetics; Molecular structures; Motifs and domains; Functional annotations; Processing and analysis of high-throughput data

recommended_readings: All recommended readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.

title: Systems Biology
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: This course introduces how systems biology combines molecular biology and genomics with physical chemistry and mathematical modeling to analyze and model the biological systems. Students learn basic concepts and properties of biological networks, as well as statistical and machine learning approaches for network analysis. Students also learn the design principles inherited in biological circuits, such as network motifs, system robustness, and optimality in biology. Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to a. know the basic principle of systems biology b. learn how to apply control theory and genetic networks on genomics and bioinformatics  c. use systems biology to solve biological and biomedical questions
syllabus: Introduction to Systems Biology;Basic concepts and properties of biological networks (I);Basic concepts and properties of biological networks (II);Workshop: Introduction to Cytoscape;Statistical and machine learning approaches for network analysis (I);Statistical and machine learning approaches for network analysis (II);Mathematical modeling in systems biology;Network motifs in transcription networks (I);Network motifs in transcription networks (II);Robustness in biological systems;Optimality in biological systems; Presentation
required_readings: All required readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
recommended_readings: 1. A First Course in Systems Biology, 2nd edition. By Eberhard O. Voit. 2017. Garland Science.  2. Mathematical Modeling in Systems Biology: An Introduction. By Brian P. Ingalls. 2013. MIT Press.

title: Genome Informatics
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: This course introduces the knowledge of genomics and bioinformatics with comprehensive aspects. Students will learn the concepts and methods for different categories of genomic studies, including reference genome studies, population genomic studies, and practical applications of genomics. In each of these categories of studies, basic knowledge as well as most recent progress will be presented. In addition to theoretical lectures, students will also have hands-on practice of the mentioned tools, thus they will have a better idea about genomics and bioinformatics. Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to: know the basic principle of and pipeline for sequencing and genomic studies; know the current progress of genomic studies; learn how to analyze the second-generation sequencing data; learn how to use/apply different bioinformatics tools; learn how to conduct a genomic study.
syllabus: Overview of genome informatics; Sequencing to provide genome information; Genome assembly to obtain the reference genome; Reference genome based studies; Hands-on study on reference genome analysis; Resequencing to identify genomic variations; Genomic variation based studies (I) & (II); Hands-on study on resequencing analysis; Using genome sequencing as a tool for other researches; Using genome sequencing as a tool for applications; Summary of genome informatics
required_readings: All required readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
recommended_readings: All recommended readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.

title: Research Project
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: Students are required to conduct a research project on a current topic in genomics and bioinformatics under the research supervisors at the Chinese University of Hong Kong. This course gives students an insight into how research is carried out in the fields of bioinformatics, with selected research techniques and data analysis approaches. It provides students the opportunity to develop and enhance their analytical and problem-solving skills through hands-on research. This course also provides practice in writing project reports and presenting scientific findings at the end of the course.Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to a. design the strategy and methodology to solve a research question  b. conduct experiments by implementing the research plan c. interpret and integrate experimental results to answer the research question d. present the research finding in the format of a written report and an oral presentation
syllabus: Each student is required to conduct a research project, submit a research proposal and a final report, and also give an oral presentation. Students and supervisors are matched subject to the mutual agreement.

recommended_readings: All recommended readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
